misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array indexing starts at 1 (off-by-one indexing model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are 1-indexed (valid indices are 1..n) and that using index n refers to the last element, index 1 refers to the first element.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed: valid indices are 0..n-1. Accessing y[n] or y[1] for a size-n array is incorrect (y[n] is always out of bounds; y[1] is the second element). This leads to runtime errors and incorrect shifting logic.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when reading input into y[i] with i==n, and again in shifting with y[n]. Even if it didn’t crash, the algorithm would shift the wrong positions (skipping index 0 entirely).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays in Java are 1-indexed, similar to some other programming languages or mathematical conventions. They think that valid array indices start at 1 rather than 0, and that index 0 is either invalid or reserved.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed. Valid indices for an array of size n range from 0 to n-1. By starting all loops at i=1 and accessing y[n], the student skips the element at index 0 and attempts to access an out-of-bounds index at y[n], which is invalid for an array of size n. This causes the code to read input into indices 1 through n (skipping index 0), read from an uninitialized out-of-bounds location y[n], and output indices 1 through n (skipping index 0).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program fails to store or process the first element correctly, skips index 0 entirely, and attempts to access y[n] which is out of bounds, leaving garbage or 0 values in the output. For the sample input [1, 2, 3, 4], the output would be incorrect and incomplete.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays use 1-based indexing, where the first element is at index 1 and the last element of an array of size N is at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java uses zero-based indexing for arrays. For an array of size N, the valid indices range from 0 to N-1. The student's model assumes index 0 is not used and index N is a valid memory location, which contradicts the actual Java execution model where index N is out of bounds.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed from 1 to n (inclusive), so the first element is y[1] and the last element is y[n].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0..n-1. Using indices 1..n will skip index 0 and attempt to access index n, which is out of bounds and causes a runtime exception.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) for most n>0, so the program will not produce the required shifted output.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Input-checking misconception: loop progresses even without consuming a valid integer
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that using hasNextInt() inside the loop is enough to ensure exactly N integers are read into the array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Because i increments every iteration regardless of whether an integer was actually read, non-integer input (or missing input) will cause the loop to advance without filling an array slot, leaving default 0s and not truly reading N integers.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output / partially uninitialized array values when input is not exactly N integers (even though the prompt implies N integers will be provided).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays start at index 1, similar to mathematical sequences or certain other programming languages. They think an array of size N can be accessed from index 1 to N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed. An array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. The student's mental model does not account for this fundamental characteristic of Java arrays. When they create int[n], they get indices 0 through n-1, but they treat it as if indices 1 through n are valid.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: When n=4, the code attempts to access y[4] during the input reading phase (line 12: y[i]=t with i=4), which is out of bounds for an array of size 4. Additionally, y[0] remains uninitialized (default value 0), causing incorrect output even if the exception were somehow avoided.

evidence.code_snippet: y[i]=t; // i starts at 1 and goes up to n, so with n=4, this accesses y[1], y[2], y[3], y[4]
int[] y=new int[n]; // Creates array with indices 0 to n-1
int i=1; while(i<=n){ ... } // Loop starts at 1, not 0, treating array as 1-indexed
int t=y[n]; // Tries to access index n in an array of size n (out of bounds)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed starting from 1 up to the length of the array (N), rather than starting from 0 up to N-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's memory model, arrays are 0-indexed. An array declared with size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. Accessing index N or starting an iteration at 1 and ending at N ignores the first element (index 0) and attempts to access memory outside the allocated bounds.
